Dispute in discourse
Dispute in discourse

Site navigation

    by Erik Hoversten

Table of contents

Abstract

Disputing an utterance can be an important tool in collaborative inquiry. In this paper, I examine a simple dialogue involving dispute and consider two established proposals for analyzing the semantic and pragmatic import of the utterances it contains. While each provides valuable insight into the interpretation of the discourse, I maintain that each is lacking in a some regard and that collaborative update semantics, supplemented with a semantics for bare plurals, offers an extension that fully accounts for the natural interpretation of the dialogue.

class="page-content">\n <div class="chapter-content">\n <p>The sticky situation for the universal interpretation of bare plurals is that sentences like <a href="#hibernating-bears-ex" id="hibernating-bears-show" class="tooled">Hibernate</a> can be true even though there are examples of non-hibernating bears, which is to say the the bare plural sentence can be true even though witnesses to its negation exist in the domain. We are alternately pulled between an inclination to view bare plural quantification as strict and an inclination to loosen it up.</p>\n\n<p>The CU extraction stands behind the strictness inclination. Bare plural sentences involve universal quantification, albeit a partitioned version thereof. The resulting puzzle is to explain (or explain away) the looseness inclination. This ultimately involves giving up on the claims that sentences such as <a href="#hibernating-bears-ex" id="hibernating-bears-show" class="tooled">Hibernate</a> are true in any rigid sense, but the framework of CU gives us a substitute that makes it easier to let go.</p>\n\n<p>The key observation here is <a href="#susceptibility-obs" id="susceptibility-show" class="tooled">Susceptibility</a>. Even if bare plural sentences can be true, their truth seems to be inherently unstable. A shift to a slightly different context</p>\n\n </div>\n</div>\n\n<div class="page.end">\n <div class="chapter-end" markdown="1">\n\n\n\n\n\n</div>\n\n</div>\n”, “content”=>”<p>The sticky situation for the universal interpretation of bare plurals is that sentences like <a href="#hibernating-bears-ex" id="hibernating-bears-show" class="tooled">Hibernate</a> can be true even though there are examples of non-hibernating bears, which is to say the the bare plural sentence can be true even though witnesses to its negation exist in the domain. We are alternately pulled between an inclination to view bare plural quantification as strict and an inclination to loosen it up.</p>\n\n<p>The CU extraction stands behind the strictness inclination. This ultimately involves giving up on the claims that sentences such as <a href="#hibernating-bears-ex" id="hibernating-bears-show" class="tooled">Hibernate</a> are true in any rigid sense, but the framework of CU gives us a substitute that makes it easier to let go.</p>\n\n<p>The key observation here is <a href="#susceptibility-obs" id="susceptibility-show" class="tooled">Susceptibility</a>. Correction as downdate

{“layout”=>”part”, “count”=>{“def”=>14, “ex”=>25, “obs”=>6, “table”=>1}, “references”=>”spenader2009+geurts1998a+geurtsa+geurts1998a+geurtsa+agm1985+levi1980+gillies2004+karttunen1979+spenader2009+jackendoff1972+rooth1985+rooth1992+rooth1985+rooth1992+hamblin1958+groenendijk1984+roberts1996+roberts1996+buering2003+buering2003+thomason1990+kehler2000+hume1777+goodman1940+goodman1940+vonfintel2008+vonfintel2008+pelletierms+lobner1987+vonfintel1997+schwarzschild1994+vonfintel1997+veltman1996+codd1970+gillies2007+stalnaker1968+lewis1973+gillies2007+kaplan1977+”, “title”=>”Correction as downdate”, “chapter”=>”Dispute in discourse”, “output”=>”<!DOCTYPE html>\n<html>\n\n<head>\n <meta http-equiv="Content-Type" content="text/html; charset=UTF-8" />\n <meta http-equiv="Content-Style-Type" content="text/css" />\n <meta name="viewport" content="width=device-width, initial-scale=1" /> <meta charset="utf-8">\n <meta http-equiv="X-UA-Compatible" content="IE=edge">\n <meta name="generator" content="jekyll" />\n\n <meta name="description" content="I contend that conversation commonly realizes a collaborative inquiry, which is to say that successful contribution to the discourse requires the efforts of multiple parties working in concert, not just serially. class="page-content">\n <div class="chapter-content">\n <h1 id="denial-as-downdate">Denial as downdate</h1>\n\n<p>Before we get to my preferred account, it is worth exploring another approach to discourses such as <a href="#bears-ex" id="bears-show" class="tooled">Bears</a> that does give pride of linguistic place to the corrective element of the completion utterance.</p>\n\n<p>The completion utterance is distinctively disputative. It seems to simultaneously deny the original statement and substitute an alternative to it. Jennifer Spenader and Emar Maier (<a id="spenader2009" class="ref tooled" href="#ref-spenader2009"><span class="date"><span class="year">2009</span></span></a>), expanding on work of Maier and Bart Geurts (<a id="geurts1998a" class="ref tooled" href="#ref-geurts1998a"><span class="date"><span class="year">1998</span></span></a>, <a id="geurtsa" class="ref tooled" href="#ref-geurtsa"><span class="date"><span class="year">2003</span></span></a>), attempt to treat corrections as downdates on the information state. On this proposal, the function of corrections is to remove from the discourse representation something that was previous added to it. A wrinkle is that corrections do not eliminate information wholesale. Consider, for example:</p>\n\n<p>In this section, I examine the downdate account of denial in terms of its ability to capture the observations about <a href="#bears-ex" id="bears-show" class="tooled">Bears</a> noted earlier.</p>\n\n<h2 id="denial-and-ldrt">Denial and LDRT</h2>\n\n<p>In his discussion of negation in its denial making use, Bart Geurts (<a id="geurts1998a" class="ref tooled" href="#ref-geurts1998a"><span class="date"><span class="year">1998</span></span></a>) maintains that denial is neither unitary nor swamping. It is not unitary beacause there are a wide variety of ways in which negation can encode denial, and there is little reason to believe that a single mechanism subsumes tham all. It is not swamping in that negation selectively denies bits of information conveyed by an utterance, granting other bits space in the conversational record.1</p>\n\n\n<div class="def" id="movie-ex"><div class="title"><span class="head">Example 1 </span>(Movie)</div><div class="body fence">\n<div class="example"><div class="item"><span class="name">A: </span><span class="content">The movie was funny.</span></div><div class="item"><span class="name">B’: </span><span class="content">The movie wasn’t [funny]f, it was [hilarious]f.</span></div><div class="item"><span class="name">B’’: </span><span class="content">[The]f movie wasn’t funny, they [all]f were.</span></div><div class="item"><span class="name">B’’’: </span><span class="content">The [movie]f wasn’t funny, the [film]f was.</span></div></div>\n</div></div>\n<div id="movie-show-tip" class="tooltip defn"><b style="border-bottom: 1px solid #fff;">Movie</b>
\n <div class="example"><div class="item"><span class="name">A: </span><span class="content">The movie was funny.</span></div><div class="item"><span class="name">B’: </span><span class="content">The movie wasn’t [funny]f, it was [hilarious]f.</span></div><div class="item"><span class="name">B’’: </span><span class="content">[The]f movie wasn’t funny, they [all]f were.</span></div><div class="item"><span class="name">B’’’: </span><span class="content">The [movie]f wasn’t funny, the [film]f was.</span></div></div>\n</div>\n\n<p>In <a href="#movie" id="movie-show" class="tooled">Movie</a>, the initiation carries a packet of information. In the responses, we alternately have denial of an implicature (a), a presupposition (b), and a choice of words (c). In each case, the rest of the packet remains untouched, and may even be available for anaphoric reference later on.</p>\n\n<p>In standard DRT, extended discourse is represented by a discourse representation structure (DRS), which is a pair of sequences of discourse referents (dref) and conditions (cond). Conditions place constraints on the model against which sentences are evaluated for truth, and drefs serve as the referents of pronouns and other anaphoric expressions invoked in the conditions. Sentences in context contribute conditions and drefs to the DRS by adding them to the appropriate sequence.</p>\n\n\n<div class="def" id="standard-drt-def"><div class="title"><span class="head">Definition 1 </span>(Standard DRT)</div><div class="body fence">\n<div class="molecule" id="drs"><div class="title">Drs</div><div class="atom"><div class="fxn eqn"><div class="pre"></div><div class="lhs"><div class="fxn eqn"><div class="pre"></div><div class="lhs">φ</div><div class="conn">=</div><div class="rhs"><span class="bit"><div class="fxn drswrap"><div class="pre"><span class="drs left top bottom"></span></div><div class="dref">φd</div><div class="conditions">φc</div><div class="post"><span class="drs right top bottom"></span></div></div></span></div><div class="post"></div></div></div><div class="conn">is</div><div class="rhs">a discourse representation structure (DRS)</div><div class="post"></div></div></div><div class="atom"><div class="molecule" id="drefs"><div class="title">Drefs</div><div class="atom"><div class="fxn eqn"><div class="pre"></div><div class="lhs">φd</div><div class="conn">is</div><div class="rhs">a sequence of drefs introduced in the discourse</div><div class="post"></div></div></div></div></div><div class="atom"><div class="molecule" id="conditions"><div class="title">Conditions</div><div class="atom"><div class="fxn eqn"><div class="pre"></div><div class="lhs">φc</div><div class="conn">is</div><div class="rhs">a sequence of conditions, imposing constraints on the
model against which sentences are evaluated</div><div class="post"></div></div></div></div></div></div>\n<hr />\n\n<div class="molecule" id="contributions"><div class="title">Contributions</div><div class="atom"><span class="categorical">For all a sentence S, uttered in discourse D, represented by DRS φ, </span></div><div class="atom"><div class="molecule" id="drefs"><div class="title">Drefs</div><div class="atom"><div class="fxn eqn"><div class="pre"></div><div class="lhs">Sd</div><div class="conn">is</div><div class="rhs">the sequence of drefs contributed by S,</div><div class="post"></div></div></div></div></div><div class="atom"><div class="molecule" id="conditions"><div class="title">Conditions</div><div class="atom"><div class="fxn eqn"><div class="pre"></div><div class="lhs">Sc</div><div class="conn">is</div><div class="rhs">the sequence of conditions contributed by S.</div><div class="post"></div></div></div></div></div><div class="atom"><div class="molecule" id="sentences"><div class="title">Sentences</div><div class="atom"><div class="fxn eqn"><div class="pre"></div><div class="lhs">D ⇒ S</div><div class="conn">=</div><div class="rhs"><div class="fxn drswrap"><div class="pre"><span class="drs left top bottom"></span></div><div class="dref">φd ⊕ Sd</div><div class="conditions">φc ⊕ Sc</div><div class="post"><span class="drs right top bottom"></span></div></div></div><div class="post"></div></div></div></div></div></div>\n</div></div>\n<div id="standard-drt-show-tip" class="tooltip defn">\n <div class="molecule" id="drs"><div class="title">Drs</div><div class="atom"><div class="fxn eqn"><div class="pre"></div><div class="lhs"><div class="fxn eqn"><div class="pre"></div><div class="lhs">φ</div><div class="conn">=</div><div class="rhs"><span class="bit"><div class="fxn drswrap"><div class="pre"><span class="drs left top bottom"></span></div><div class="dref">φd</div><div class="conditions">φc</div><div class="post"><span class="drs right top bottom"></span></div></div></span></div><div class="post"></div></div></div><div class="conn">is</div><div class="rhs">a discourse representation structure (DRS)</div><div class="post"></div></div></div><div class="atom"><div class="molecule" id="drefs"><div class="title">Drefs</div><div class="atom"><div class="fxn eqn"><div class="pre"></div><div class="lhs">φd</div><div class="conn">is</div><div class="rhs">a sequence of drefs introduced in the discourse</div><div class="post"></div></div></div></div></div><div class="atom"><div class="molecule" id="conditions"><div class="title">Conditions</div><div class="atom"><div class="fxn eqn"><div class="pre"></div><div class="lhs">φc</div><div class="conn">is</div><div class="rhs">a sequence of conditions, imposing constraints on the
model against which sentences are evaluated</div><div class="post"></div></div></div></div></div></div>\n <hr />\n <div class="molecule" id="contributions"><div class="title">Contributions</div><div class="atom"><span class="categorical">For all a sentence S, uttered in discourse D, represented by DRS φ, </span></div><div class="atom"><div class="molecule" id="drefs"><div class="title">Drefs</div><div class="atom"><div class="fxn eqn"><div class="pre"></div><div class="lhs">Sd</div><div class="conn">is</div><div class="rhs">the sequence of drefs contributed by S,</div><div class="post"></div></div></div></div></div><div class="atom"><div class="molecule" id="conditions"><div class="title">Conditions</div><div class="atom"><div class="fxn eqn"><div class="pre"></div><div class="lhs">Sc</div><div class="conn">is</div><div class="rhs">the sequence of conditions contributed by S.</div><div class="post"></div></div></div></div></div><div class="atom"><div class="molecule" id="sentences"><div class="title">Sentences</div><div class="atom"><div class="fxn eqn"><div class="pre"></div><div class="lhs">D ⇒ S</div><div class="conn">=</div><div class="rhs"><div class="fxn drswrap"><div class="pre"><span class="drs left top bottom"></span></div><div class="dref">φd ⊕ Sd</div><div class="conditions">φc ⊕ Sc</div><div class="post"><span class="drs right top bottom"></span></div></div></div><div class="post"></div></div></div></div></div></div>\n</div>\n\n<p>Standard DRT, only defines an update function for sentences, but there is nothing preventing us from defining a downdate, whereby conditions or drefs are removed from the DRS. But in standard DRT, all information contributed by a sentence is added to the conditions sequence. Thus, removing information removes it wholesale, which is to say that standard DRT makes denial swamping.</p>\n\n<p>To account for the selective nature of denial, Geurts and Maier (<a id="geurtsa" class="ref tooled" href="#ref-geurtsa"><span class="date"><span class="year">2003</span></span></a>) develop Layered Discourse Representation Theory (LDRT). LDRT avoids swamping by indexing all information conveyed by a sentence (both conditions ad drefs) by its kind, which is a matter of the discourse function it performs. The system can recognize such kinds as asserted content (fr), presupposed content (pr), implicated content (inf), contextual information (k), and information about syntactic and phonological form (fm). The effect is that the information added to a DRS is segmented into different layers. Certain conditions and drefs may get reduplicated in different layers if that information plays multiple roles in the discourse. We will represent the layer to which a bit of information is assigned by a subscript on condition or dref it contributes.</p>\n\n<p>To downdate, then, is to remove information from the DRS, but removing information of the presuppositional variety does nothing to the same information duplicated at the propositional level. The result is non-swamping denial.</p>\n\n<p>There is an additional complication for the denial-as-downdate approach, familiar from the literature on belief revision (<a id="agm1985" class="ref tooled" href="#ref-agm1985"><span class="author">Alchóurron et al. </span><span class="date"><span class="year">1985</span></span></a>, <a id="levi1980" class="ref tooled" href="#ref-levi1980"><span class="author">Levi </span><span class="date"><span class="year">1980</span></span></a>). An information state is always downdated in response to some impetus. The principal reason for performing a downdate is that the state has just been updated into incoherence, which is to say that an update operation has introduced information that contradicts information already present in the state. The role of the downdate is to remove enough information from the state to restore it to coherence. The problem is that, in general, there are multiple ways to perform this operation.</p>\n\n<p>As an example (<a id="gillies2004" class="ref tooled" href="#ref-gillies2004"><span class="author">Gillies </span><span class="date"><span class="year">2004</span></span></a>), imagine I happen to believe both that at least one of coffeeshop A or B is open (p∨q) and that coffeeshop A is open (p), which we represent as the deductive closure of the set containing these two beliefs: Cn({ p∨q, p }). But I subsequently get strong evidence that coffeeshop A is not open, say I see a sign hanging in the door that reads “Closed all day for cleaning”. Updating with this new evidence results in the belief state Cn({ p∨q, p, ¬p }), which is just the universal set. I believe too much, and I must revise. But how much do I remove? Minimally, p will have to go. But what about p∨q? The choice depends on the details of my epistemic situation.</p>\n\n<p>Suppose I had seen you walking down the street carrying a cup of coffee. Knowing that there are only two coffee shops in town, I came to believe that at least one of them is open (p∨q). Continuing along, I saw lights on in coffeeshop A, which led me to update my belief set with p. Only when I got closer did I see the sign. In this case, I have independent reason for my belief that one of the coffeeshops is open, and it seems that p∨q deserves to remain. It seems that a minimal retraction, excising only the directly contradictory p, is the strategy that is called for.</p>\n\n<p>But suppose, instead, that my first bit of evidence is the light coming from coffeeshop A. Since Cn({ p }) contains p∨q, I similarly have to decide what to do with the disjunction when I read the sign. In this case, the natural response is that it gets swept out along with the removal of p. Minimal retraction fails to capture the derivative status of my belief in the disjunction.</p>\n\n<p>The upshot is that the propositional content of the evidence that initiates the downdate is not sufficient to determine the extent of the downdate; we need, also, a way of representing the source of certain propositions that are candidates for removal. The standard solution is to supplement the information state structure with an entrenchment relation, which serves to rank elements of the state in terms of their susceptibility to removal. This puts constraints on how and information state is revised in response to its falling into incoherence: remove the information needed to restore coherence as well as any unentrenched information relevant to the retracted information.2 Crucially, the entrenchment relation constrains appropriate retraction, but it does not fix a unique revision strategy.</p>\n\n\n<div class="def" id="correction-as-downdate-def"><div class="title"><span class="head">Definition 2 </span>(Correction as downdate)</div><div class="body fence">\n<div class="molecule"><div class="title"></div><div class="atom"><span class="categorical">φ,ψ,χ: <span class="var">drs</span></span>, </div><div class="atom"><div class="fxn eqn"><div class="pre"></div><div class="lhs"><div class="fxn eqn"><div class="pre"></div><div class="lhs">χ</div><div class="conn">⊑</div><div class="rhs">φ</div><div class="post"></div></div></div><div class="conn">iff</div><div class="rhs">∃m [ ( m ∈ φd ∧ m ∈ χd ) ∨ ( m ∈ φc ∧ m ∈ χc ) ]</div><div class="post"></div></div></div><div class="atom"><div class="fxn eqn"><div class="pre"></div><div class="lhs"><div class="fxn eqn"><div class="pre"></div><div entrench(<span class="var">c</span>) ] ∧ ¬∃φ ( ψ ⊑ φ ∧ χ ⊑ ψ )</div><div class="post"></div></div></div><div class="atom"><div class="fxn eqn"><div class="pre"></div><div class="lhs"><div class="fxn drswrap"><div class="pre"><span class="drs left top bottom"></span></div><div class="dref">φd ⊕ Sd</div><div class="conditions">φc ⊕ Sc</div><div class="post"><span class="drs right top )</div><div class="post"></div></div></div></div>\n</div></div>\n<div id="correction-as-downdate-show-tip" class="tooltip defn">\n <div class="molecule"><div class="title"></div><div class="atom"><span class="categorical">φ,ψ,χ: <span class="var">drs</span></span>, </div><div class="atom"><div class="fxn eqn"><div class="pre"></div><div class="lhs"><div class="fxn eqn"><div class="pre"></div><div class="lhs">χ</div><div class="conn">⊑</div><div class="rhs">φ</div><div class="post"></div></div></div><div class="conn">iff</div><div class="rhs">∃m [ ( m ∈ φd ∧ m ∈ χd ) ∨ ( m ∈ φc ∧ m ∈ χc ) ]</div><div class="post"></div></div></div><div class="atom"><div class="fxn eqn"><div class="pre"></div><div class="lhs"><div class="fxn eqn"><div class="pre"></div><div entrench(<span class="var">c</span>) ] ∧ ¬∃φ ( ψ ⊑ φ ∧ χ ⊑ ψ )</div><div class="post"></div></div></div><div class="atom"><div class="fxn eqn"><div class="pre"></div><div class="lhs"><div class="fxn eqn"><div class="pre"></div><div class="lhs">φ</div><div class="conn">⊞</div><div class="rhs">ψ</div><div class="post"></div></div></div><div class="conn">=</div><div class="rhs"><div class="fxn drswrap"><div class="pre"><span class="drs left top bottom"></span></div><div class="dref">φd ⊕ Sd</div><div class="conditions">φc ⊕ Sc</div><div class="post"><span class="drs right top bottom"></span></div></div></div><div class="post"></div></div></div><div class="atom"><div class="fxn eqn"><div class="pre"></div><div class="lhs"><div class="fxn eqn"><div class="pre"></div><div class="lhs">φ</div><div class="conn"><span class="symbol">↓</span></div><div class="rhs">ψ</div><div class="post"></div></div></div><div class="conn">=</div><div class="rhs">ψ ⊕ max( χ ⊑ φ | χ ⊞ φ ≠ ∅ )</div><div class="post"></div></div></div></div>\n</div>\n\n<h3 id="binding-retractions">Binding retractions</h3>\n\n<p>The LDRT approach provides an adequate explanation of certain cases of denial, but it does so by taking incidental advantage of an artefact of the DRT framework. A genuine solution would recognize that the value of DRSs is not that they allow for boundary crossing drefs specifically, but that they manage to interleave bits of information that play different interpretive roles. The dref/condition distinction is one such distinction in roles, but it is not the only one that potentially gives rise to binding-style problems. For example, BAF have shown that interaction between content types is also present for the at-issue/not-at-issue distinction:</p>\n\n<p>The binding problem, originally introduced in a endnote to Karttunen and Peters’ Conventional Implicature (<a id="karttunen1979" class="ref tooled" href="#ref-karttunen1979"><span class="date"><span class="year">1979</span></span></a>). In the system expounded in that paper, conventional implicature is set apart as a distinct dimension of content from the standard semantic content derived from the meaning of the words in a sentence and the way they are put together. Cleaving implicature from semantic content allows us to explain a number of interesting features about how conventional implicatures work, but it also makes it more difficult to explain the ways in which elements of semantic content can interact with elements of the implicature.</p>\n\n\n<div class="def" id="managed-ex"><div class="title"><span class="head">Example 2 </span>(Managed)</div><div class="body fence">\n<div class="example"><div class="item"><span class="name">A: </span><span class="content">Someone managed to succeed George V on the throne of England.</span></div><div class="item"><span class="name">B: </span><span class="content">If someone managed to succeed George V on the throne of England, then that country is still a monarchy.</span></div></div>\n</div></div>\n<div id="managed-show-tip" class="tooltip defn"><b style="border-bottom: 1px solid #fff;">Managed</b>
\n <div class="example"><div class="item"><span class="name">A: </span><span class="content">Someone managed to succeed George V on the throne of England.</span></div><div class="item"><span class="name">B: </span><span class="content">If someone managed to succeed George V on the throne of England, then that country is still a monarchy.</span></div></div>\n</div>\n\n<p>The (a) sentence in <a href="#managed-ex" id="managed-show" class="tooled">Managed</a> seems to implicate that the person who succeeded George V on the throne had difficulty in doing so. But the most natural way of representing the implicature as derived from the utterred sentence is does not capture this.</p>\n\n\n<div class="def" id="managed-semantics-ex"><div class="title"><span class="head">Example 3 </span>(Managed semantics)</div><div class="body fence">\n<div class="example"><div class="item"><span class="name">Asem: </span><span class="content">∃x,y ( george(x) ∧ succeeded(y,x) )</span></div><div class="item"><span class="name">Aimp: </span><span class="content">∃x,y ( george(x) ∧ succeeded(y,x) ∧ had-difficulty(x) )</span></div></div>\n</div></div>\n<div id="managed-semantics-show-tip" class="tooltip defn"><b style="border-bottom: 1px solid #fff;">Managed semantics</b>
\n <div class="example"><div class="item"><span class="name">Asem: </span><span class="content">∃x,y ( george(x) ∧ succeeded(y,x) )</span></div><div class="item"><span class="name">Aimp: </span><span class="content">∃x,y ( george(x) ∧ succeeded(y,x) ∧ had-difficulty(x) )</span></div></div>\n</div>\n\n<p>And it is finding such inroads between severed contents that is termed the binding problem. The separation between levels of content also provides a way around the swamping worry for denial, but because the LDRT approach involves dividing content by way of indexing, we may be concerned that a binding problem will arise here as well.</p>\n\n<p>But the system has a built in fix that it acquires from the structure of DRSs. In LDRT, while conditions are isolated in their layer, drefs are not. While drefs are introduced in a layer, they transcend that position and are shared by conditions at all layers. Thus, they form a glue that binds layers together just enough to avoid the binding worries.</p>\n\n<p>At least, they avoid binding worries associated with drefs, such as Geurts and Maier’s problem with madrigals.</p>\n\n\n<div class="def" id="madrigals-ex"><div class="title"><span class="head">Example 4 </span>(Madrigals)</div><div class="body fence">\n<div class="example"><div class="item"><span class="content">Some of the madrigals are nice.</span></div></div>\n</div></div>\n<div id="madrigals-show-tip" class="tooltip defn"><b style="border-bottom: 1px solid #fff;">Madrigals</b>
\n <div class="example"><div class="item"><span class="content">Some of the madrigals are nice.</span></div></div>\n</div>\n\n<p><a href="#madrigals" id="madrigals-show" class="tooled">Madrigals</a> carries two implicatures in addition to its assertive content. It implicates first that not all of the madrigals are nice and also that the nice madrigals are merely nice. The first of these does not give rise to binding concerns, for there is no need to connect the discourse referent intdroduced by the existential quantifier to the variable bound by the implicated not-all quantifier. But the second does; if we represent implicated and asserted content as fully separated, then we fail to get capture the constraint that the merely nice madrigals are the same as the nice ones.</p>\n\n<p>However, by allowing drefs to transcend layers, we can adequately link the conditions. Here is Geurts and Maier’s analysis:3</p>\n\n\n<div class="def" id="madrigals-ex"><div class="title"><span class="head">Example 5 </span>(Madrigals)</div><div class="body fence">\n<div class="example"><div class="item">madrigals</div></div>\n</div></div>\n<div id="madrigals-show-tip" class="tooltip defn"><b style="border-bottom: 1px solid #fff;">Madrigals</b>
\n <div class="example"><div class="item">madrigals</div></div>\n</div>\n\n<p>Jennifer Spenader joins Maier (<a id="spenader2009" class="ref tooled" href="#ref-spenader2009"><span class="date"><span class="year">2009</span></span></a>) in extending this approach to account also for the corrective potential of contrast. According to the extension, contrast is a general means of preventing material from entering the common ground. It’s presence signifies that the information in its scope is being presented for a downdate operation.</p>\n\n\n<div class="def" id="spanish-ex"><div class="title"><span class="head">Example 6 </span>(Spanish)</div><div class="body fence">\n<div class="example"><div class="item"><span class="name">A: </span><span class="content">Juan speaks Spanish.</span></div><div class="item"><span class="name">B: </span><span class="content">Well, he is Argentinian, but he doesn’t speak Spanish.</span></div></div>\n</div></div>\n<div id="spanish-show-tip" class="tooltip defn"><b style="border-bottom: 1px solid #fff;">Spanish</b>
\n <div class="example"><div class="item"><span class="name">A: </span><span class="content">Juan speaks Spanish.</span></div><div class="item"><span class="name">B: </span><span class="content">Well, he is Argentinian, but he doesn’t speak Spanish.</span></div></div>\n</div>\n\n<p>In the completion of <a href="#spanish-ex" id="spanish-show" class="tooled">Spanish</a>, the choice of connective (but) carries contrastive import; the second conjunct, in its scope, is a downdating correction of the initiation sentence. The first conjuct, preceded by the hedge term well, provides a concession to the initiation, indicating that the response is intended as a refinement rather than a swamping denial.</p>\n\n\n<div class="def" id="spanish-semantics-ex"><div class="title"><span class="head">Example 7 </span>(Spanish semantics)</div><div class="body fence">\n<div class="example"><div class="item">spanish</div></div>\n</div></div>\n<div id="spanish-semantics-show-tip" class="tooltip defn"><b style="border-bottom: 1px solid #fff;">Spanish semantics</b>
\n <div class="example"><div class="item">spanish</div></div>\n</div>\n\n<h1 id="collaborative-inquiry-and-bare-plurals">Collaborative inquiry and bare plurals</h1>\n\n<p>The general collaborative update framework, <a href="/theory">developed in the previous chapter</a>, forms the backbone of my preferred analysis of <a href="#bears-ex" id="bears-show" class="tooled">Bears</a>. But the specifics of the discourse dynamics are partially determined by the semantic structure of the particular utterance involved. I suggest that collaborative effects assert themselves in the discourse through the conduit of the bare plural subjects. In the broadest possible strokes, the analysis interprets bare plural expressions as a form of universal quantifier, what I call structurally universal quantifiers. The semantic rules of structurally universal quantifiers reference both context and the pragmatic rules of collaborative discourse in determining their quantificational domain. This appeal to both semantic and pragmatic rules in the analysis means that we do not have a fully general pragmatic solution, and there is some reason to prefer a general approach to focus-related effects.</p>\n\n </div>\n</div>\n\n<div class="page.end">\n <div class="chapter-end" markdown="1">\n\n\n\n\n\n</div>\n\n</div>\n”, “content”=>”<h1 id="denial-as-downdate">Denial as downdate</h1>\n\n<p>Before we get to my preferred account, it is worth exploring another approach to discourses such as <a href="#bears-ex" id="bears-show" class="tooled">Bears</a> that does give pride of linguistic place to the corrective element of the completion utterance.</p>\n\n<p>The completion utterance is distinctively disputative. It seems to simultaneously deny the original statement and substitute an alternative to it. Jennifer Spenader and Emar Maier (<a id="spenader2009" class="ref tooled" href="#ref-spenader2009"><span class="date"><span class="year">2009</span></span></a>), expanding on work of Maier and Bart Geurts (<a id="geurts1998a" class="ref tooled" href="#ref-geurts1998a"><span class="date"><span class="year">1998</span></span></a>, <a id="geurtsa" class="ref tooled" href="#ref-geurtsa"><span class="date"><span class="year">2003</span></span></a>), attempt to treat corrections as downdates on the information state. On this proposal, the function of corrections is to remove from the discourse representation something that was previous added to it. A wrinkle is that corrections do not eliminate information wholesale. Consider, for example:</p>\n\n<p>In this section, I examine the downdate account of denial in terms of its ability to capture the observations about <a href="#bears-ex" id="bears-show" class="tooled">Bears</a> noted earlier.</p>\n\n<h2 id="denial-and-ldrt">Denial and LDRT</h2>\n\n<p>In his discussion of negation in its denial making use, Bart Geurts (<a id="geurts1998a" class="ref tooled" href="#ref-geurts1998a"><span class="date"><span class="year">1998</span></span></a>) maintains that denial is neither unitary nor swamping. It is not unitary beacause there are a wide variety of ways in which negation can encode denial, and there is little reason to believe that a single mechanism subsumes tham all. It is not swamping in that negation selectively denies bits of information conveyed by an utterance, granting other bits space in the conversational record.1</p>\n\n\n<div class="def" id="movie-ex"><div class="title"><span class="head">Example 1 </span>(Movie)</div><div class="body fence">\n<div class="example"><div class="item"><span class="name">A: </span><span class="content">The movie was funny.</span></div><div class="item"><span class="name">B’: </span><span class="content">The movie wasn’t [funny]f, it was [hilarious]f.</span></div><div class="item"><span class="name">B’’: </span><span class="content">[The]f movie wasn’t funny, they [all]f were.</span></div><div class="item"><span class="name">B’’’: </span><span class="content">The [movie]f wasn’t funny, the [film]f was.</span></div></div>\n</div></div>\n<div id="movie-show-tip" class="tooltip defn"><b style="border-bottom: 1px solid #fff;">Movie</b>
\n <div class="example"><div class="item"><span class="name">A: </span><span class="content">The movie was funny.</span></div><div class="item"><span class="name">B’: </span><span class="content">The movie wasn’t [funny]f, it was [hilarious]f.</span></div><div class="item"><span class="name">B’’: </span><span class="content">[The]f movie wasn’t funny, they [all]f were.</span></div><div class="item"><span class="name">B’’’: </span><span class="content">The [movie]f wasn’t funny, the [film]f was.</span></div></div>\n</div>\n\n<p>In <a href="#movie" id="movie-show" class="tooled">Movie</a>, the initiation carries a packet of information. In the responses, we alternately have denial of an implicature (a), a presupposition (b), and a choice of words (c). In each case, the rest of the packet remains untouched, and may even be available for anaphoric reference later on.</p>\n\n<p>In standard DRT, extended discourse is represented by a discourse representation structure (DRS), which is a pair of sequences of discourse referents (dref) and conditions (cond). Conditions place constraints on the model against which sentences are evaluated for truth, and drefs serve as the referents of pronouns and other anaphoric expressions invoked in the conditions. Sentences in context contribute conditions and drefs to the DRS by adding them to the appropriate sequence.</p>\n\n\n<div class="def" id="standard-drt-def"><div class="title"><span class="head">Definition 1 </span>(Standard DRT)</div><div class="body fence">\n<div class="molecule" id="drs"><div class="title">Drs</div><div class="atom"><div class="fxn eqn"><div class="pre"></div><div class="lhs"><div class="fxn eqn"><div class="pre"></div><div class="lhs">φ</div><div class="conn">=</div><div class="rhs"><span class="bit"><div class="fxn drswrap"><div class="pre"><span class="drs left top bottom"></span></div><div class="dref">φd</div><div class="conditions">φc</div><div class="post"><span class="drs right top bottom"></span></div></div></span></div><div class="post"></div></div></div><div class="conn">is</div><div class="rhs">a discourse representation structure (DRS)</div><div class="post"></div></div></div><div class="atom"><div class="molecule" id="drefs"><div class="title">Drefs</div><div class="atom"><div class="fxn eqn"><div class="pre"></div><div class="lhs">φd</div><div class="conn">is</div><div class="rhs">a sequence of drefs introduced in the discourse</div><div class="post"></div></div></div></div></div><div class="atom"><div class="molecule" id="conditions"><div class="title">Conditions</div><div class="atom"><div class="fxn eqn"><div class="pre"></div><div class="lhs">φc</div><div class="conn">is</div><div class="rhs">a sequence of conditions, imposing constraints on the
model against which sentences are evaluated</div><div class="post"></div></div></div></div></div></div>\n<hr />\n\n<div class="molecule" id="contributions"><div class="title">Contributions</div><div class="atom"><span class="categorical">For all a sentence S, uttered in discourse D, represented by DRS φ, </span></div><div class="atom"><div class="molecule" id="drefs"><div class="title">Drefs</div><div class="atom"><div class="fxn eqn"><div class="pre"></div><div class="lhs">Sd</div><div class="conn">is</div><div class="rhs">the sequence of drefs contributed by S,</div><div class="post"></div></div></div></div></div><div class="atom"><div class="molecule" id="conditions"><div class="title">Conditions</div><div class="atom"><div class="fxn eqn"><div class="pre"></div><div class="lhs">Sc</div><div class="conn">is</div><div class="rhs">the sequence of conditions contributed by S.</div><div class="post"></div></div></div></div></div><div class="atom"><div class="molecule" id="sentences"><div class="title">Sentences</div><div class="atom"><div class="fxn eqn"><div class="pre"></div><div class="lhs">D ⇒ S</div><div class="conn">=</div><div class="rhs"><div class="fxn drswrap"><div class="pre"><span class="drs left top bottom"></span></div><div class="dref">φd ⊕ Sd</div><div class="conditions">φc ⊕ Sc</div><div class="post"><span class="drs right top bottom"></span></div></div></div><div class="post"></div></div></div></div></div></div>\n</div></div>\n<div id="standard-drt-show-tip" class="tooltip defn">\n <div class="molecule" id="drs"><div class="title">Drs</div><div class="atom"><div class="fxn eqn"><div class="pre"></div><div class="lhs"><div class="fxn eqn"><div class="pre"></div><div class="lhs">φ</div><div class="conn">=</div><div class="rhs"><span class="bit"><div class="fxn drswrap"><div class="pre"><span class="drs left top bottom"></span></div><div class="dref">φd</div><div class="conditions">φc</div><div class="post"><span class="drs right top bottom"></span></div></div></span></div><div class="post"></div></div></div><div class="conn">is</div><div class="rhs">a discourse representation structure (DRS)</div><div class="post"></div></div></div><div class="atom"><div class="molecule" id="drefs"><div class="title">Drefs</div><div class="atom"><div class="fxn eqn"><div class="pre"></div><div class="lhs">φd</div><div class="conn">is</div><div class="rhs">a sequence of drefs introduced in the discourse</div><div class="post"></div></div></div></div></div><div class="atom"><div class="molecule" id="conditions"><div class="title">Conditions</div><div class="atom"><div class="fxn eqn"><div class="pre"></div><div class="lhs">φc</div><div class="conn">is</div><div class="rhs">a sequence of conditions, imposing constraints on the
model against which sentences are evaluated</div><div class="post"></div></div></div></div></div></div>\n <hr />\n <div class="molecule" id="contributions"><div class="title">Contributions</div><div class="atom"><span class="categorical">For all a sentence S, uttered in discourse D, represented by DRS φ, </span></div><div class="atom"><div class="molecule" id="drefs"><div class="title">Drefs</div><div class="atom"><div class="fxn eqn"><div class="pre"></div><div class="lhs">Sd</div><div class="conn">is</div><div class="rhs">the sequence of drefs contributed by S,</div><div class="post"></div></div></div></div></div><div class="atom"><div class="molecule" id="conditions"><div class="title">Conditions</div><div class="atom"><div class="fxn eqn"><div class="pre"></div><div class="lhs">Sc</div><div class="conn">is</div><div class="rhs">the sequence of conditions contributed by S.</div><div class="post"></div></div></div></div></div><div class="atom"><div class="molecule" id="sentences"><div class="title">Sentences</div><div class="atom"><div class="fxn eqn"><div class="pre"></div><div class="lhs">D ⇒ S</div><div class="conn">=</div><div class="rhs"><div class="fxn drswrap"><div class="pre"><span class="drs left top bottom"></span></div><div class="dref">φd ⊕ Sd</div><div class="conditions">φc ⊕ Sc</div><div class="post"><span class="drs right top bottom"></span></div></div></div><div class="post"></div></div></div></div></div></div>\n</div>\n\n<p>Standard DRT, only defines an update function for sentences, but there is nothing preventing us from defining a downdate, whereby conditions or drefs are removed from the DRS. But in standard DRT, all information contributed by a sentence is added to the conditions sequence. Thus, removing information removes it wholesale, which is to say that standard DRT makes denial swamping.</p>\n\n<p>To account for the selective nature of denial, Geurts and Maier (<a id="geurtsa" class="ref tooled" href="#ref-geurtsa"><span class="date"><span class="year">2003</span></span></a>) develop Layered Discourse Representation Theory (LDRT). LDRT avoids swamping by indexing all information conveyed by a sentence (both conditions ad drefs) by its kind, which is a matter of the discourse function it performs. The system can recognize such kinds as asserted content (fr), presupposed content (pr), implicated content (inf), contextual information (k), and information about syntactic and phonological form (fm). The effect is that the information added to a DRS is segmented into different layers. Certain conditions and drefs may get reduplicated in different layers if that information plays multiple roles in the discourse. We will represent the layer to which a bit of information is assigned by a subscript on condition or dref it contributes.</p>\n\n<p>To downdate, then, is to remove information from the DRS, but removing information of the presuppositional variety does nothing to the same information duplicated at the propositional level. The result is non-swamping denial.</p>\n\n<p>There is an additional complication for the denial-as-downdate approach, familiar from the literature on belief revision (<a id="agm1985" class="ref tooled" href="#ref-agm1985"><span class="author">Alchóurron et al. </span><span class="date"><span class="year">1985</span></span></a>, <a id="levi1980" class="ref tooled" href="#ref-levi1980"><span class="author">Levi </span><span class="date"><span class="year">1980</span></span></a>). An information state is always downdated in response to some impetus. The principal reason for performing a downdate is that the state has just been updated into incoherence, which is to say that an update operation has introduced information that contradicts information already present in the state. The role of the downdate is to remove enough information from the state to restore it to coherence. The problem is that, in general, there are multiple ways to perform this operation.</p>\n\n<p>As an example (<a id="gillies2004" class="ref tooled" href="#ref-gillies2004"><span class="author">Gillies </span><span class="date"><span class="year">2004</span></span></a>), imagine I happen to believe both that at least one of coffeeshop A or B is open (p∨q) and that coffeeshop A is open (p), which we represent as the deductive closure of the set containing these two beliefs: Cn({ p∨q, p }). But I subsequently get strong evidence that coffeeshop A is not open, say I see a sign hanging in the door that reads “Closed all day for cleaning”. Updating with this new evidence results in the belief state Cn({ p∨q, p, ¬p }), which is just the universal set. I believe too much, and I must revise. But how much do I remove? Minimally, p will have to go. But what about p∨q? The choice depends on the details of my epistemic situation.</p>\n\n<p>Suppose I had seen you walking down the street carrying a cup of coffee. Knowing that there are only two coffee shops in town, I came to believe that at least one of them is open (p∨q). Continuing along, I saw lights on in coffeeshop A, which led me to update my belief set with p. Only when I got closer did I see the sign. In this case, I have independent reason for my belief that one of the coffeeshops is open, and it seems that p∨q deserves to remain. It seems that a minimal retraction, excising only the directly contradictory p, is the strategy that is called for.</p>\n\n<p>But suppose, instead, that my first bit of evidence is the light coming from coffeeshop A. Since Cn({ p }) contains p∨q, I similarly have to decide what to do with the disjunction when I read the sign. In this case, the natural response is that it gets swept out along with the removal of p. Minimal retraction fails to capture the derivative status of my belief in the disjunction.</p>\n\n<p>The upshot is that the propositional content of the evidence that initiates the downdate is not sufficient to determine the extent of the downdate; we need, also, a way of representing the source of certain propositions that are candidates for removal. The standard solution is to supplement the information state structure with an entrenchment relation, which serves to rank elements of the state in terms of their susceptibility to removal. This puts constraints on how and information state is revised in response to its falling into incoherence: remove the information needed to restore coherence as well as any unentrenched information relevant to the retracted information.2 Crucially, the entrenchment relation constrains appropriate retraction, but it does not fix a unique revision strategy.</p>\n\n\n<div class="def" id="correction-as-downdate-def"><div class="title"><span class="head">Definition 2 </span>(Correction as downdate)</div><div class="body fence">\n<div class="molecule"><div class="title"></div><div class="atom"><span class="categorical">φ,ψ,χ: <span class="var">drs</span></span>, </div><div class="atom"><div class="fxn eqn"><div class="pre"></div><div class="lhs"><div class="fxn eqn"><div class="pre"></div><div class="lhs">χ</div><div class="conn">⊑</div><div class="rhs">φ</div><div class="post"></div></div></div><div class="conn">iff</div><div class="rhs">∃m [ ( m ∈ φd ∧ m ∈ χd ) ∨ ( m ∈ φc ∧ m ∈ χc ) ]</div><div class="post"></div></div></div><div class="atom"><div class="fxn eqn"><div class="pre"></div><div class="lhs"><div class="fxn eqn"><div class="pre"></div><div entrench(<span class="var">c</span>) ] ∧ ¬∃φ ( ψ ⊑ φ ∧ χ ⊑ ψ )</div><div class="post"></div></div></div><div class="atom"><div class="fxn eqn"><div class="pre"></div><div class="lhs"><div class="fxn drswrap"><div class="pre"><span class="drs left top bottom"></span></div><div class="dref">φd ⊕ Sd</div><div class="conditions">φc ⊕ Sc</div><div class="post"><span class="drs right top bottom"></span></div></div></div><div class="post"></div></div></div><div class="atom"><div class="fxn eqn"><div class="pre"></div><div class="lhs"><div class="fxn eqn"><div class="pre"></div><div class="lhs">φ</div><div class="conn"><span class="symbol">↓</span></div><div class="rhs">ψ</div><div class="post"></div></div></div><div class="conn">=</div><div class="rhs">ψ ⊕ max( χ ⊑ φ | χ ⊞ φ ≠ ∅ )</div><div class="post"></div></div></div></div>\n</div></div>\n<div id="correction-as-downdate-show-tip" class="tooltip defn">\n <div class="molecule"><div class="title"></div><div class="atom"><span class="categorical">φ,ψ,χ: <span class="var">drs</span></span>, </div><div class="atom"><div class="fxn eqn"><div class="pre"></div><div class="lhs"><div class="fxn eqn"><div class="pre"></div><div class="lhs">χ</div><div class="conn">⊑</div><div class="rhs">φ</div><div class="post"></div></div></div><div class="conn">iff</div><div class="rhs">∃m [ ( m ∈ φd ∧ m ∈ χd ) ∨ ( m ∈ φc ∧ m ∈ χc ) ]</div><div class="post"></div></div></div><div class="atom"><div class="fxn eqn"><div class="pre"></div><div class="lhs"><div class="fxn eqn"><div class="pre"></div><div class="lhs">χ</div><div class="conn">=</div><div class="rhs">max(φ)</div><div class="post"></div></div></div><div class="conn">iff</div><div class="rhs">χ ⊑ φ ∧ ∀<span class="var">c</span> ∈ φc [ entrench(<span class="var">c</span>) ] ∧ ¬∃φ ( ψ ⊑ φ ∧ χ ⊑ ψ )</div><div class="post"></div></div></div><div class="atom"><div class="fxn eqn"><div class="pre"></div><div class="lhs"><div class="fxn eqn"><div class="pre"></div><div class="lhs">φ</div><div class="conn">⊞</div><div class="rhs">ψ</div><div class="post"></div></div></div><div class="conn">=</div><div class="rhs"><div class="fxn drswrap"><div class="pre"><span class="drs left top bottom"></span></div><div class="dref">φd ⊕ Sd</div><div class="conditions">φc ⊕ Sc</div><div class="post"><span class="drs right top bottom"></span></div></div></div><div class="post"></div></div></div><div class="atom"><div class="fxn eqn"><div class="pre"></div><div class="lhs"><div class="fxn eqn"><div class="pre"></div><div class="lhs">φ</div><div class="conn"><span class="symbol">↓</span></div><div class="rhs">ψ</div><div class="post"></div></div></div><div class="conn">=</div><div class="rhs">ψ ⊕ max( χ ⊑ φ | χ ⊞ φ ≠ ∅ )</div><div class="post"></div></div></div></div>\n</div>\n\n<h3 id="binding-retractions">Binding retractions</h3>\n\n<p>The LDRT approach provides an adequate explanation of certain cases of denial, but it does so by taking incidental advantage of an artefact of the DRT framework. A genuine solution would recognize that the value of DRSs is not that they allow for boundary crossing drefs specifically, but that they manage to interleave bits of information that play different interpretive roles. The dref/condition distinction is one such distinction in roles, but it is not the only one that potentially gives rise to binding-style problems. For example, BAF have shown that interaction between content types is also present for the at-issue/not-at-issue distinction:</p>\n\n<p>The binding problem, originally introduced in a endnote to Karttunen and Peters’ Conventional Implicature (<a id="karttunen1979" class="ref tooled" href="#ref-karttunen1979"><span class="date"><span class="year">1979</span></span></a>). In the system expounded in that paper, conventional implicature is set apart as a distinct dimension of content from the standard semantic content derived from the meaning of the words in a sentence and the way they are put together. Cleaving implicature from semantic content allows us to explain a number of interesting features about how conventional implicatures work, but it also makes it more difficult to explain the ways in which elements of semantic content can interact with elements of the implicature.</p>\n\n\n<div class="def" id="managed-ex"><div class="title"><span class="head">Example 2 </span>(Managed)</div><div class="body fence">\n<div class="example"><div class="item"><span class="name">A: </span><span class="content">Someone managed to succeed George V on the throne of England.</span></div><div class="item"><span class="name">B: </span><span class="content">If someone managed to succeed George V on the throne of England, then that country is still a monarchy.</span></div></div>\n</div></div>\n<div id="managed-show-tip" class="tooltip defn"><b style="border-bottom: 1px solid #fff;">Managed</b>
\n <div class="example"><div class="item"><span class="name">A: </span><span class="content">Someone managed to succeed George V on the throne of England.</span></div><div class="item"><span class="name">B: </span><span class="content">If someone managed to succeed George V on the throne of England, then that country is still a monarchy.</span></div></div>\n</div>\n\n<p>The (a) sentence in <a href="#managed-ex" id="managed-show" class="tooled">Managed</a> seems to implicate that the person who succeeded George V on the throne had difficulty in doing so. But the most natural way of representing the implicature as derived from the utterred sentence is does not capture this.</p>\n\n\n<div class="def" id="managed-semantics-ex"><div class="title"><span class="head">Example 3 </span>(Managed semantics)</div><div class="body fence">\n<div class="example"><div class="item"><span class="name">Asem: </span><span class="content">∃x,y ( george(x) ∧ succeeded(y,x) )</span></div><div class="item"><span class="name">Aimp: </span><span class="content">∃x,y ( george(x) ∧ succeeded(y,x) ∧ had-difficulty(x) )</span></div></div>\n</div></div>\n<div id="managed-semantics-show-tip" class="tooltip defn"><b style="border-bottom: 1px solid #fff;">Managed semantics</b>
\n <div class="example"><div class="item"><span class="name">Asem: </span><span class="content">∃x,y ( george(x) ∧ succeeded(y,x) )</span></div><div class="item"><span class="name">Aimp: </span><span class="content">∃x,y ( george(x) ∧ succeeded(y,x) ∧ had-difficulty(x) )</span></div></div>\n</div>\n\n<p>And it is finding such inroads between severed contents that is termed the binding problem. The separation between levels of content also provides a way around the swamping worry for denial, but because the LDRT approach involves dividing content by way of indexing, we may be concerned that a binding problem will arise here as well.</p>\n\n<p>But the system has a built in fix that it acquires from the structure of DRSs. In LDRT, while conditions are isolated in their layer, drefs are not. While drefs are introduced in a layer, they transcend that position and are shared by conditions at all layers. Thus, they form a glue that binds layers together just enough to avoid the binding worries.</p>\n\n<p>At least, they avoid binding worries associated with drefs, such as Geurts and Maier’s problem with madrigals.</p>\n\n\n<div class="def" id="madrigals-ex"><div class="title"><span class="head">Example 4 </span>(Madrigals)</div><div class="body fence">\n<div class="example"><div class="item"><span class="content">Some of the madrigals are nice.</span></div></div>\n</div></div>\n<div id="madrigals-show-tip" class="tooltip defn"><b style="border-bottom: 1px solid #fff;">Madrigals</b>
\n <div class="example"><div class="item"><span class="content">Some of the madrigals are nice.</span></div></div>\n</div>\n\n<p><a href="#madrigals" id="madrigals-show" class="tooled">Madrigals</a> carries two implicatures in addition to its assertive content. It implicates first that not all of the madrigals are nice and also that the nice madrigals are merely nice. The first of these does not give rise to binding concerns, for there is no need to connect the discourse referent intdroduced by the existential quantifier to the variable bound by the implicated not-all quantifier. But the second does; if we represent implicated and asserted content as fully separated, then we fail to get capture the constraint that the merely nice madrigals are the same as the nice ones.</p>\n\n<p>However, by allowing drefs to transcend layers, we can adequately link the conditions. Here is Geurts and Maier’s analysis:3</p>\n\n\n<div class="def" id="madrigals-ex"><div class="title"><span class="head">Example 5 </span>(Madrigals)</div><div class="body fence">\n<div class="example"><div class="item">madrigals</div></div>\n</div></div>\n<div id="madrigals-show-tip" class="tooltip defn"><b style="border-bottom: 1px solid #fff;">Madrigals</b>
\n <div class="example"><div class="item">madrigals</div></div>\n</div>\n\n<p>Jennifer Spenader joins Maier (<a id="spenader2009" class="ref tooled" href="#ref-spenader2009"><span class="date"><span class="year">2009</span></span></a>) in extending this approach to account also for the corrective potential of contrast. According to the extension, contrast is a general means of preventing material from entering the common ground. It’s presence signifies that the information in its scope is being presented for a downdate operation.</p>\n\n\n<div class="def" id="spanish-ex"><div class="title"><span class="head">Example 6 </span>(Spanish)</div><div class="body fence">\n<div class="example"><div class="item"><span class="name">A: </span><span class="content">Juan speaks Spanish.</span></div><div class="item"><span class="name">B: </span><span class="content">Well, he is Argentinian, but he doesn’t speak Spanish.</span></div></div>\n</div></div>\n<div id="spanish-show-tip" class="tooltip defn"><b style="border-bottom: 1px solid #fff;">Spanish</b>
\n <div class="example"><div class="item"><span class="name">A: </span><span class="content">Juan speaks Spanish.</span></div><div class="item"><span class="name">B: </span><span class="content">Well, he is Argentinian, but he doesn’t speak Spanish.</span></div></div>\n</div>\n\n<p>In the completion of <a href="#spanish-ex" id="spanish-show" class="tooled">Spanish</a>, the choice of connective (but) carries contrastive import; the second conjunct, in its scope, is a downdating correction of the initiation sentence. The first conjuct, preceded by the hedge term well, provides a concession to the initiation, indicating that the response is intended as a refinement rather than a swamping denial.</p>\n\n\n<div class="def" id="spanish-semantics-ex"><div class="title"><span class="head">Example 7 </span>(Spanish semantics)</div><div class="body fence">\n<div class="example"><div class="item">spanish</div></div>\n</div></div>\n<div id="spanish-semantics-show-tip" class="tooltip defn"><b style="border-bottom: 1px solid #fff;">Spanish semantics</b>
\n <div class="example"><div class="item">spanish</div></div>\n</div>\n\n<h1 id="collaborative-inquiry-and-bare-plurals">Collaborative inquiry and bare plurals</h1>\n\n<p>The general collaborative update framework, <a href="/theory">developed in the previous chapter</a>, forms the backbone of my preferred analysis of <a href="#bears-ex" id="bears-show" class="tooled">Bears</a>. But the specifics of the discourse dynamics are partially determined by the semantic structure of the particular utterance involved. I suggest that collaborative effects assert themselves in the discourse through the conduit of the bare plural subjects. In the broadest possible strokes, the analysis interprets bare plural expressions as a form of universal quantifier, what I call structurally universal quantifiers. The semantic rules of structurally universal quantifiers reference both context and the pragmatic rules of collaborative discourse in determining their quantificational domain. This appeal to both semantic and pragmatic rules in the analysis means that we do not have a fully general pragmatic solution, and there is some reason to prefer a general approach to focus-related effects.</p>\n”, “path”=>”/home/erik/kitioi/_parts/did/correction-as-downdate.md”, “relative_path”=>”_parts/did/correction-as-downdate.md”, “url”=>”/parts/did/correction-as-downdate”, “collection”=>”parts”}

Features of Bears

It is the goal of this project to explain, motivate, and provide a model of implementation for this idea, what I call collaborative discourse dynamics.">\n Features of Bears\n\n <link rel="canonical" \n <li><a href="/parts/did/correction-as-downdate">Correction as downdate</a></li>\n \n \n \n <li><a href="/parts/did/features-of-bears">Features of Bears</a></li>\n \n \n \n <li><a shifts</a></li>\n \n \n </ul>\n\n <div class="title">Features of Bears</div>\n <div class="subtitle">Dispute in discourse</div>\n <div class="divider"></div>\n\n</div>\n\n<div class="page-content">\n <div class="chapter-content">\n <p>There are two salient linguistic features of the Bears dialogue to which I would like to draw attention: utterance A has a bare plural subject and utterance B involves focus within its subject. There is a standard treatment for each of these features. In this section, I briefly outline the standard treatments.</p>\n\n<h2 id="bare-plurals">Bare plurals</h2>\n\n<p>Bare plural subjects can have different functions in different linguistic contexts. Though they have identical surface form, the subject in each of the following examples plays a very different role.</p>\n\n\n<div class="def" id="bear-plurals-ex"><div class="title"><span class="head">Example 8 </span>(Bear Plurals)</div><div class="body fence">\n<div class="example"><div class="item"><span class="name">A: </span><span class="content">Bears are in the field.</span></div><div class="item"><span class="name">B: </span><span class="content">Bears are mammals.</span></div><div class="item"><span class="name">C: </span><span class="content">Bears are widespread.</span></div></div>\n</div></div>\n<div id="bear-plurals-show-tip" class="tooltip defn"><b style="border-bottom: 1px solid #fff;">Bear Plurals</b>
\n <div class="example"><div class="item"><span class="name">A: </span><span class="content">Bears are in the field.</span></div><div class="item"><span class="name">B: </span><span class="content">Bears are mammals.</span></div><div class="item"><span class="name">C: </span><span class="content">Bears are widespread.</span></div></div>\n</div>\n\n<p>In A, the subject is a specific group of particular bears. In this guise, the bare plural is existential. In B, we are generalizing over the entire class of bears; thus, the subject is being employed in its characterizing guise. And finally, in C, we are referring directly to a kind and attributing a property to it.</p>\n\n<p>The guise that is relevant for our topic dialogue is the characterizing use, and that is what our discussion will focus on here. The standard view of the logical form of sentences with generic bare plural subjects treats them as having an implicit two-place quantifier (GEN) with the subject as restrictor and the predicate as scope.</p>\n\n<p>Under this analysis, there are three main questions that must be answered:</p>\n\n<ol>\n <li>What is the nature of GEN?</li>\n <li>What is the domain of quantification?</li>\n <li>What the relationship of the restrictor class to the subject class?</li>\n</ol>\n\n<h3 id="domain">Domain</h3>\n\n<p>As a species of adverbial quantification, the domain of GEN is typically taken to be a set of cases (situations or worlds).</p>\n\n<h3 id="normalcy">Normalcy</h3>\n\n<p>Generics can absorb counterexamples, and sometimes quite a few. So, GEN is distinctly not a universal quantifier. A standard proposal is that GEN requires that the predicate hold in all normal cases relative to the subject. That is, the restrictor has two functions: it pares down the set of cases that are relevant to the quantification and it determines a normalcy condition on the restricted class. This effectively partitions the restricted class into preferred and dispreferred groups. The generic will be true just in case all predicate cases are in the preferred group. So construed, GEN is really a universal quantifier; it is merely one that relativized to a sub-class of the domain cases.</p>\n\n<p>My proposal provides an implementation of this structural quantification view</p>\n\n<h2 id="characterizing-generics">Characterizing generics</h2>\n\n<p>Characterizing generics are doubly slippery: their force is amorphous and they are both susceptible and resilient.</p>\n\n<p>It’s common to talk of GEN as an operator with less than universal force. But this isn’t quite accurate. Really, it is a universal quantifier over a (contextually) restricted sub-class of the subject.</p>\n\n<p>Where, then, do we locate the preference ranking function? It could be indexically supplied or is could involve an index shift. By making it a context shifting mechanism, we can better capture susceptibility and resilience, which are results of collaborative mechanisms.</p>\n\n<p>So, generics are structural universals. The structure is supplied by the focus alternative set. But it is supplied in a collaborative, delayed way.</p>\n\n<h2 id="focus">Focus</h2>\n\n </div>\n</div>\n\n<div class="page.end">\n <div class="chapter-end" markdown="1">\n\n\n\n\n\n</div>\n\n</div>\n”, “content”=>”<p>There are two salient linguistic features of the Bears dialogue to which I would like to draw attention: utterance A has a bare plural subject and utterance B involves focus within its subject. There is a standard treatment for each of these features. In this section, I briefly outline the standard treatments.</p>\n\n<h2 id="bare-plurals">Bare plurals</h2>\n\n<p>Bare plural subjects can have different functions in different linguistic contexts. Though they have identical surface form, the subject in each of the following examples plays a very different role.</p>\n\n\n<div class="def" id="bear-plurals-ex"><div class="title"><span class="head">Example 8 </span>(Bear Plurals)</div><div class="body fence">\n<div class="example"><div class="item"><span class="name">A: </span><span class="content">Bears are in the field.</span></div><div class="item"><span class="name">B: </span><span class="content">Bears are mammals.</span></div><div class="item"><span class="name">C: </span><span class="content">Bears are widespread.</span></div></div>\n</div></div>\n<div id="bear-plurals-show-tip" class="tooltip defn"><b style="border-bottom: 1px solid #fff;">Bear Plurals</b>
\n <div class="example"><div class="item"><span class="name">A: </span><span class="content">Bears are in the field.</span></div><div class="item"><span class="name">B: </span><span class="content">Bears are mammals.</span></div><div class="item"><span class="name">C: </span><span class="content">Bears are widespread.</span></div></div>\n</div>\n\n<p>In A, the subject is a specific group of particular bears. In this guise, the bare plural is existential. In B, we are generalizing over the entire class of bears; thus, the subject is being employed in its characterizing guise. And finally, in C, we are referring directly to a kind and attributing a property to it.</p>\n\n<p>The guise that is relevant for our topic dialogue is the characterizing use, and that is what our discussion will focus on here. The standard view of the logical form of sentences with generic bare plural subjects treats them as having an implicit two-place quantifier (GEN) with the subject as restrictor and the predicate as scope.</p>\n\n<p>Under this analysis, there are three main questions that must be answered:</p>\n\n<ol>\n <li>What is the nature of GEN?</li>\n <li>What is the domain of quantification?</li>\n <li>What the relationship of the restrictor class to the subject class?</li>\n</ol>\n\n<h3 id="domain">Domain</h3>\n\n<p>As a species of adverbial quantification, the domain of GEN is typically taken to be a set of cases (situations or worlds).</p>\n\n<h3 id="normalcy">Normalcy</h3>\n\n<p>Generics can absorb counterexamples, and sometimes quite a few. So, GEN is distinctly not a universal quantifier. A standard proposal is that GEN requires that the predicate hold in all normal cases relative to the subject. That is, the restrictor has two functions: it pares down the set of cases that are relevant to the quantification and it determines a normalcy condition on the restricted class. This effectively partitions the restricted class into preferred and dispreferred groups. The generic will be true just in case all predicate cases are in the preferred group. So construed, GEN is really a universal quantifier; it is merely one that relativized to a sub-class of the domain cases.</p>\n\n<p>My proposal provides an implementation of this structural quantification view</p>\n\n<h2 id="characterizing-generics">Characterizing generics</h2>\n\n<p>Characterizing generics are doubly slippery: their force is amorphous and they are both susceptible and resilient.</p>\n\n<p>It’s common to talk of GEN as an operator with less than universal force. But this isn’t quite accurate. Really, it is a universal quantifier over a (contextually) restricted sub-class of the subject.</p>\n\n<p>Where, then, do we locate the preference ranking function? It could be indexically supplied or is could involve an index shift. By making it a context shifting mechanism, we can better capture susceptibility and resilience, which are results of collaborative mechanisms.</p>\n\n<p>So, generics are structural universals. The structure is supplied by the focus alternative set. But it is supplied in a collaborative, delayed way.</p>\n\n<h2 id="focus">Focus</h2>\n”, “path”=>”/home/erik/kitioi/_parts/did/features-of-bears.md”, “relative_path”=>”_parts/did/features-of-bears.md”, “url”=>”/parts/did/features-of-bears”, “collection”=>”parts”}

Focus

{“layout”=>”part”, “count”=>{“def”=>14, “ex”=>25, “obs”=>6, “table”=>1}, “references”=>”spenader2009+geurts1998a+geurtsa+geurts1998a+geurtsa+agm1985+levi1980+gillies2004+karttunen1979+spenader2009+jackendoff1972+rooth1985+rooth1992+rooth1985+rooth1992+hamblin1958+groenendijk1984+roberts1996+roberts1996+buering2003+buering2003+thomason1990+kehler2000+hume1777+goodman1940+goodman1940+vonfintel2008+vonfintel2008+pelletierms+lobner1987+vonfintel1997+schwarzschild1994+vonfintel1997+veltman1996+codd1970+gillies2007+stalnaker1968+lewis1973+gillies2007+kaplan1977+”, “title”=>”Focus”, “chapter”=>”Dispute in discourse”, “output”=>”<!DOCTYPE html>\n<html>\n\n<head>\n <meta http-equiv="Content-Type" content="text/html; charset=UTF-8" />\n <meta http-equiv="Content-Style-Type" content="text/css" />\n <meta name="viewport" content="width=device-width, initial-scale=1" /> <meta charset="utf-8">\n <meta http-equiv="X-UA-Compatible" content="IE=edge">\n <meta name="generator" content="jekyll" />\n\n <meta name="description" content="I contend that conversation commonly realizes a collaborative inquiry, which is to say that successful contribution to the discourse requires the efforts of multiple parties working in concert, not just serially. It is the goal of this project to explain, motivate, and provide a model of implementation for this idea, what I call collaborative discourse dynamics.">\n Focus\n\n <link rel="canonical"
